packageRepo.readme:
Med-Expansions

A comprehensive and systematic set of keyboard expansions for medical note-taking using Espanso

Install ‚Ä¢ Demo ‚Ä¢ Key Features ‚Ä¢ How To Use ‚Ä¢ Credits ‚Ä¢ License

# Install `espanso install med-expansions` ## Demo ![screenshot](./demo.gif) ## Key Features * **Systematic** - forget remembering complicated triggers - Simple rules yield consistent results. * **Cut down on typing** - Medical terminology is often painfully protracted to type, often for no good reason, if you need to type supraventricular tachycardia often, you're going to love this package. * **We have it all covered** - Viruses, fungi, pathology, clinical terminology, everything medical, we've got it down‚Ä†. * **Cross platform** - Windows, macOS and Linux enabled, thanks to [Espanso](http://espanso.org "Espanso") ‚Ä† *this is totally a lie (for now)* ## How To Use Legend: * `SPC` refers to the spacebar ##### RULE #1 ###### If the expansion is a common acronym*, the trigger **is the acronym** *followed by a trailing* `.` e.g ‚Äî (ACS, BP, HTN), triggers are: * `acs. ‚Üí acute coronary syndrome` * `bp. ‚Üí blood pressure` * `htn. ‚Üí hypertension` - If the expansion is not referred to by its acronym (like `jp ‚Üí J-point`), a trailing `.` is not required * Press `SPC` after typing the `.` and the trigger will expand. ##### RULE #2 ###### If the expansion is a medical term with **multiple syllables*** , the trigger is the **first LETTER** *followed by* the **first THREE letters** of the ***first* distinguishing syllable**. e.g ‚Äî (pneumothorax, cardiomegaly, pleural effusion), triggers are: * `ptho ‚Üí pneuomothorax` * `cmeg ‚Üí cardiomegaly` * `peff ‚Üí pleural effusion` * *"Distinguishing syllable"* in this context refers to the first syllable *that distinguishes the word from other words*. This means that `cardiomegaly` has a trigger of `cmeg`, as opposed to `cdio`, because many words will have a first letter of c and second syllable starting with "dio". * This sounds complicated but 95%+ of the time, it is extremely intuitive and will probably be what rolls off your tongue naturally * `Cardiac tamponade` is `ctam`, `pleural effusion` is `peff`, `rhabdomyolysis` is `rmyo` etc. * Why do it this way? It's the way we most naturally think of shorthand terms, think about `afib` and `vfib`, which follow this rule. * Where this rule is not possible to follow, which is rare, a common sense alternative is used * If rule #1 or #2 (whichever not first applied) can be used, **and** a common-sense/intuitive alternative exists, **BOTH** will be valid triggers. Otherwise, ONLY the intuitive trigger is valid * An effort is made to document exceptions with comments (lines above the trigger line marked with a `#`) in the .yml files ##### RULE #3 > For bacteria / fungi, the following is always a valid trigger (except in salmonella enteritidis and Bacillus anthracis) ###### First letter of genus followed by first three letters of species followed by `SPC` * Where an intuitive expansion exists that does not follow the above, both are valid triggers * e.g ‚Äî While the rule for Haemophilus influenzae is hinf (first letter of Haemophilus is H, first three letters of influenza is inf). But "hflu" is the most reasonable trigger here * So, in this case (and in similar cases), both "hflu" and "hinf" are both valid triggers Exceptions are the following working triggers `Senter ‚Üí Salmonella enteritidis` and `banth ‚Üí Bacillus anthracis` ##### RULE #4a ###### For Viruses, *if the virus is one or two short syllables* followed by `virus` (e.g `togavirus`), the trigger is simply the first syllable followed by `v`·µÉ ##### RULE #4b ###### For viruses with *multiple syllables*, the trigger is the **first letter**, followed by the **first two letters from the next distinguishing syllable** followed by `v` * `omyv ‚Üí Orthomyxovirus` * `crov ‚Üí Coronaviridae` * **Plurals**: adding two `v`'s at the end will yield the plural form * `crovv ‚Üí Coronaviridae` * For ease of use, and for consistency, *in future*, simply applying **rule #2** alone and adding a trailing v will trigger the expansion (i.e ‚Äî `Orthomyxovirus` will be triggered by `omyv` as per **rule #4b** and `omyx` as per **rule #2** and `omyxv` as a fallback) ·µÉ ‚Äî * For short viruses obeying **rule #4a**, which are on the border between 4a and 4b, both triggers will be valid. #### Some notable exceptions: ##### Exception #1 ###### Common shorthand follows a simple rule, take the common shorthand and append a trailing "." and press `SPC` * E.g: * `tx. ‚Üí treatment`. `hx. ‚Üí history`. * etc. * `qds. ‚Üí four times daily` * `4/12. ‚Üí four month` * `hb. ‚Üí haemoglobin` * etc. * `a. ‚Üí artery` * `as. ‚Üí arteries` * etc. ## Credits This software uses the following open source packages: - [Espanso](http://espanso.org) ## License GNU GPLv3 --- > Cillian Scott ‚Ä¢ > GitHub [@CillySu](https://github.com/CillySu) ‚Ä¢ > E-mail: scottci@tcd.ie

# package med-expansion
# This YAML file includes basic general medical expansions
# TOC
    # Veins, Arteries and Nerves
    # General / Clinical high-yield
    # General NON-Clinical but universally useful expansions
# Veins / Arteries and Nerves

    # /* VIRUS FILLS START
    #/Users/cillianscott/Library/Preferences/espanso/match/packages/contractions-en/package.yml  HOW-TO USE:
    # ALL Viral expansions end in "v"
    # Letter of first syllable, letter of second syllable, first letter of third syllable OR second letter of second syllable (if only two syllables) followed by "v"
    # *O*rtho*MY*xo*V*irus ‚Üí omyv 
    # For Viruses with one syllable followed by virus (eg ‚Äî adenovirus) the entire syllable followed by  v will expand.
    # Where possible "intuitive" expansions are ALSO facilitated ON TOP OF the systematic style detailed above

      # Adenovirus can be expanded with "adev" or "adenov"

packageYml.name: ecg.yml
packageYml.content:
# ECG-related terminology
# Any expansions relating to ECG waves or findings (i.e ‚Äî stuff ON the ECG, like the different waves or intervals, segments etc) are appended with a trailing "." to expand
# intervals appended with "i" ‚Äî PR-interval is triggered with "pri.<SPC>"
# General rule is that two word or syllables are expanded with:
    # [1st_Letter_1st_Word][Chars_1,2,3_of_2nd_word/syllable]
    # So Eindhoven's Triangle is expanded with:
      # etri<SPC> ‚Üí Eindhoven's Triangle$|$
      # The placement of the cursor immediately following the expanded form is to remediate the issue raised by myself in https://github.com/espanso/espanso/issues/1411 
# Where the first word or syllable is the variable portion of the expansion (e.g ‚Äî LATeral lead, POSterior lead, INFerior lead), the rule is simply reversed
    # [Chars_1,2,3_of_1st_Word][1st_char_2nd_Syllable/Word]
# There is an attempt made to keep all expansions to four characters typically, and as a maximum.
# Shorter triggers exist where expansions are either common or where four characters would be too much squeeze for too little juice.
# Longer triggers exist typically under two circumstances
    # Shorter triggers that obey the rules are already in use by another expansion
    # The expansion in question is a derivative of another word for which an expansion already exists
      # e.g ‚Äî "prec" is the trigger for "precordial", "precl" therefore is the trigger for "precordial" leads.   
matches:
  # Misc. General but used in ECG

  # This expansion follows no rules, sorry... But better than making a separate match for every instance of interted T, inverted P, etc.
  # Intended usage: "!i.<space> tw.<SPC>" ‚Üí "Inverted T-wave$|$" 
  # "i" is included as opposed to just "!." so that you can use "!I." to yield capitalised "I" ("Inverted" as opposed to "inverted")
  - trigger: "!i"
    replace: "inverted"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true

  # R waves/intervals
  - trigger: "rw"
    replace: "R-wave$|$"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true

  - trigger: "qrs."
    replace: "QRS complex$|$"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true

  - trigger: "rri"
    replace: "RR-interval$|$"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true

  - trigger: "pri"
    replace: "PR-interval$|$"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true

  - trigger: "pw"
    replace: "P-wave$|$"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true

  - trigger: "sts"
    replace: "ST segment$|$"
    propagate_case: true
    word: true
      
      # Q wave/intervals

  - triggers: ["qtci", "qtc", "cqti"]

    propagate_case: true
    uppercase_style: "capitalize_words"
    word: true

  - trigger: "qti"

    propagate_case: true
